channel.title: A Hugo website
channel.description: Recent content on A Hugo website

item.title: performr vignette is live
item.description: Skip to the goods. About time I dusted off the cobwebs on this ol blog. I’m working hard to complete revisions on my first chapter. In preperation, I’ve made a vignette to walk through how to use my R package perfomr, which provides the core functionality that the manuscript relies on. It comes with a way to simulate data, so give it a whirl. I’ve been trying to learn more about neural networks, so maybe I’ll make a post about that (or anything really) soon … ish.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m Silas Tittes, a PhD student at CU Boulder studying with Nancy Emery and Nolan Kane. My research focuses on the development and application of methods to learn about adaptive evolution on multiple spatial and temporal scales. Please see my GitHub and Google Scholar pages to learn more. I hope this blog is useful and entertaining to others – I see it as a space to explore ideas and describe the state of my knowledge/thinking about a given topic at the time of writing.

item.title: What can we learn from spotting a Prius or two?
item.description: If you live in a wealthy, liberal town like Boulder, CO, you’ve likely seen your fair share of Toyota Prii (this is supposedly the plural of Prius). Heck, you might even own one. I decided to collect a little data. I used my iPhone stopwatch to record wait times between seeing Prii. I walked at a near-constant speed, along a more or less linear transect along 13th Street, from Arapahoe to Spruce.
